newsitem.title: USA: Institutions seen dominating flex options in U.S..
newsitem.headline: Institutions seen dominating flex options in U.S..

text.p: Institutional investors are likely to be the big players in flex options on individual U.S. shares that begin trading Thursday but some early interest is expected from curious retail customers.
"Sharp investors will figure this out pretty quickly and take advantage of it," said Marty Kearney at PTI Securities in Chicago.
"It's nice to be able to pick something a little more to your liking," he said.

Flex -- short for "flexible exchange" -- options allow investors to set their own strike prices and expirations, giving them the opportunity to tailor options closer to their hedging and speculative strategies than standard options.
"The beauty of flex is the customization of whatever the player is looking to do," said Price Headley, director of research at Cincinnati-based Investment Research Institute.

"I think (institutions) is where you're going to see interest in the flex product because you're looking at institutions that have big exposures they want to hedge," he explained. "The flex is more geared to hedging."
Analysts said the new options will have the best chance of success if the exchanges stick to listings that already have solid liquidity in the existing options and the shares.

Scott Kilrea, designated primary market maker for options on Telefonos de Mexico on the Chicago Board Options Exchange (CBOE), predicted a flood of queries for quotes when the flex options open for trading on Thursday.

"Basically it will be firms holding positions in OTC (over-the-counter) options that just want to price them," he said. "Maybe it will be the risk control people who do it, but they'll be essentially valuing stuff."
Telmex is one of 15 stocks on which flex options will be available on the American Stock Exchange (AMEX) and one of the 10 on the CBOE.
Other stocks scheduled for flex options on both the AMEX and CBOE include American Online Inc and Grupo Televisa S.A. de C.V.
Some other FLEX options on the CBOE will include Coca Cola Co, General Motors Corp and International Business Machines Corp.
On the AMEX, flex options will include American Express Co, Intel Corp and Philip Morris Cos Inc.
Also starting Thursday, the Pacific Stock Exchange plans to offer flex options on 10 companies including Compaq Computer Corp and Microsoft Corp.
The CBOE plans to offer flex options on another six stocks on November 5. They include Citicorp, Ford Motor Co and Merck and Co Inc.
The Philadelphia Stock Exchange is waiting for approval from the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission to list flex options on individual shares.
At the CBOE, flex options on the S&P 100 and 500 stock indices were launched in February 1993 and flex options on the Russell 2000 index and Nasdaq 100 index have since been added.
The AMEX currently offers flex options on its major market index, its institutional index and the S&P midcap index. Index flex options were launched in September 1993 at the AMEX.
